subtitle: Learn how robots think—through the game you love

codingConcept.name: State
keyPoints: States track what's happening in a program
Only one state can be active at a time
State management is fundamental to programming

mathConcept.name: Possession Statistics
mathConcept.mathExample:
Turnover Rate = (Turnovers / Possessions) × 100
Example: (2 turnovers / 3 possessions) × 100 = 66.7%

learningObjectives: Identify the four states of possession (START, LIVE, DEAD, OUTCOME)
Track state changes in basketball scenarios
Understand state transitions and the rules that govern them
Apply state concepts to edge cases and real-world situations
Connect coding concepts to basketball gameplay
Use AI assistance effectively with human confirmation
Calculate basic statistics (possession count, turnover rate)
Understand confidence scores and AI certainty

The center circle of Data Court glowed with a soft blue light, pulsing like a heartbeat. Nova bounced on the balls of her feet, her eyes scanning the court. She could see it all—the lines of code that made up every play, the state of every possession, the flow of data like a river of information.

"Remember," Coach Circuit's voice crackled through their earpieces, "the tip-off is where it all begins. One state becomes another. Start. Live. Dead. Outcome. That's the sequence. Don't let it glitch."

leftPage.text:
Nova's mind raced. She had to track it. She had to count.

"Three possessions," she called back. "Two turnovers. One successful—wait, no. That one ended in a shot, but it missed. So... three possessions, two turnovers, zero points."

The math was simple, but the problem was clear. Their turnover rate was too high.

skillPitStop.title: Understanding State in Code
skillPitStop.content:
Think of state like a light switch. A light switch can be in one of two states: ON or OFF. It can't be both at the same time, and it can only change from one state to the other when you flip the switch.

In basketball, and in code, we use states to track what's happening. Just like a light switch, the game can only be in one state at a time, and it changes when something specific happens.

The Four States of Possession:
1. START - When the play begins (tip-off)
2. LIVE - When the ball is in play
3. DEAD - When play stops
4. OUTCOME - When the play ends with a result

Turnover Rate = (Turnovers / Possessions) × 100

Turnovers = 2
Possessions = 3
Turnover Rate = (2 / 3) × 100 = 66.7%
